how_to.title: How to Wield GPT Image 1.5
how_to.description: Mastering this model is about specificity. The more precise your instructions, the better the output.

steps.title: 1. Select & Set Context
steps.description: Choose 'GPT Image 1.5' from the model dashboard. Unlike abstract art models, this tool thrives on context. Define your goal immediately: 'A marketing poster,' 'A UI mockup,' or 'A character sheet.'

media.alt: Interface showing the selection of GPT Image 1.5 and a context setting dropdown.

steps.title: 2. Prompt with Precision
steps.description: If you need text, use double quotes: "Text Here". If you need specific placement, use coordinates or clear prepositions: 'A red ball in the top-left corner, a blue cube in the bottom-right.' The model's logic engine will map these strictly.

media.alt: A prompt input field showing structured text with specific layout instructions.

steps.title: 3. Surgical Editing
steps.description: Don't like the background? Use the conversational edit feature. Type 'Change the background to a forest but keep the character exactly the same.' GPT Image 1.5 locks the subject's identity while swapping the environment.

media.alt: An editing interface showing a character remaining unchanged while the background cycles through different options.

useCases.title: Solving the 'Uncontrollable AI' Problem
useCases.description: Where other models hallucinate, GPT Image 1.5 executes. Here are four scenarios where precision matters more than vibes.

scenarios.tagline: Finally, an AI that passes a spelling bee.
scenarios.description: Creating a holiday sale flyer usually means generating an image and then switching to Canva to add text. With GPT Image 1.5, you can command a 'luxury perfume bottle on a velvet podium with a gold sign reading "Midnight Scent"'. The model integrates the typography physically into the 3D scene, creating reflections and shadows for the letters that 2D overlays can't match.

E-commerce managers can upload a single studio photo of a sneaker and ask the model to 'place this exact shoe on a rugged hiking trail'. Unlike older models that would reimagine the shoe and ruin the brand identity, GPT Image 1.5 identifies the product as a protected object, altering only the lighting and environment to match the new context.

image.alt: A sneaker seamlessly integrated into a rocky mountain trail environment.

scenarios.description: Graphic novelists often struggle with characters changing faces between panels. By prompting for a '2x2 grid showing the same detective reacting to evidence: 1. Shock, 2. Anger, 3. Confusion, 4. Determination', users leverage the model's spatial reasoning to generate consistent character sheets in one go, maintaining outfit and facial structure across all frames.

scenarios.tagline: Blueprints that developers can actually use.
scenarios.description: Abstract AI art is useless for web development. GPT Image 1.5 excels at following structural mandates. Requesting a 'SaaS analytics dashboard with a left sidebar, a top search bar, and a center heat map' yields a clean, geometrically accurate interface mock-up. It respects standard UI patterns and text hierarchy, speeding up the 'ideation to wireframe' pipeline.

image.alt: A clean, modern SaaS dashboard mockup with distinct UI elements.

items.question: How does GPT Image 1.5 compare to Nano Banana Pro?
items.answer: It comes down to **Precision vs. Vibe**. Nano Banana Pro is famous for its 'messy realism' and logical 3D textures, making it great for artistic concepts and figurines. GPT Image 1.5, however, wins on **control**. If you need specific text spelled correctly, a strict UI layout, or the ability to edit a background without changing the character's face, GPT Image 1.5 is the superior tool.

items.question: Can it really spell text correctly?
items.answer: Yes, significantly better than previous generations. By placing text in double quotes (e.g., "Summer Sale"), the model treats the letters as structural shapes rather than textures, resulting in high legibility for headings, signs, and logos.

items.question: Is it suitable for photorealistic images?
items.answer: Absolutely. While it defaults to a clean, commercial look, you can prompt for 'imperfect, grainy 35mm photography' to get realistic results. However, for 'accidental' or 'candid' realism, Nano Banana Pro might still have a slight edge in texture.

items.question: How does the 'Edit' feature work?
items.answer: GPT Image 1.5 supports conversational editing. Once an image is generated, you can simply type a follow-up command like 'Make it snowing' or 'Change the car to red'. The model understands which parts of the image to keep stable and which to alter.

items.question: What is the best way to prompt for layouts?
items.answer: Be explicit about geometry. Terms like 'split screen', 'knolling', 'isometric view', or describing the scene in layers (foreground, midground, background) work exceptionally well with this model.

items.question: Does it support reference images?
items.answer: Yes. You can upload an image to use as a style reference or a composition guide. This is particularly powerful when combined with text prompts to strictly control the output.

items.question: Why is it called '1.5'?
items.answer: It represents a significant mid-cycle architecture update to the core engine, bridging the gap between standard diffusion and the upcoming next-gen video models, specifically focusing on prompt understanding and text capabilities.

items.question: Can I use it for logo design?
items.answer: Yes. Because it understands negative space and text, it is currently one of the best AI models for generating vector-style logos and mascots that require clean lines and specific brand names.
